description: Latin reciprocus, possibly from a phrase such as reque proque (“back and forth, to and fro”), from re- (“back”), prō (“forwards”) and -que (“and”).

entries.meaning: Of a feeling, action or such: mutual, uniformly felt or done by each party towards the other or others; two-way.

examples: These two rules will render a definition reciprocal with the thing defined.

entries.meaning: (grammar) Expressing mutual action, applied to pronouns and verbs; also in a broad sense: reflexive.
(mathematics) Used to denote different kinds of mutual relation; often with reference to the substitution of reciprocals for given quantities.
Done, given, felt, or owed in return
(arithmetic) The number obtained by dividing 1 by another given number; the result of exchanging the numerator and the denominator of a fraction.

examples: Depending on where reciprocalization applies (syntax vs. lexicon), the relevant reciprocal verbs are claimed to exhibit specific properties, in particular: (i) syntactic reciprocals are fully productive whereas lexical reciprocals have only limited productivity;  […]
